title: Outreach and Research Resources
introduction: Introducing a nationwide toolkit and new local programs to combat last-leg impaired driving requires robust outreach and communication strategies, as well as ongoing research to refine approaches.

sections.title: Outreach and Communication Strategies
sections.content: Both stakeholders (e.g., transit agencies, businesses, community leaders) and the general public need to understand the issue and embrace the proposed solutions. The ultimate goal is behavior change – convincing individuals who might otherwise drive impaired to instead use the provided alternatives.

strategies.title: Define a Clear Public Message and Campaign
strategies.description: Frame the problem and solution in a way that resonates with the public. Many people may not have considered that "driving the short distance home from the train station can be just as dangerous as driving all the way from the city while drunk."
examples: Potential slogan: "Finish Safe: No Driving Required on Your Last Leg Home"
Highlight that impaired driving is dangerous no matter the distance
Use positive messaging that reinforces smart choices
Develop consistent visual branding for the campaign

strategies.title: Leverage Multiple Communication Channels
strategies.description: To reach the target audience (which includes commuters, event-goers, and generally 21–50-year-olds who go out and might drink), use a multichannel outreach approach.
examples: Traditional media: TV and radio news segments
Social media: geotargeted ads on platforms like Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram
Printed materials: posters and signage at strategic locations
Educational outreach: informational booths at events or transit stations

strategies.title: Engage and Educate Stakeholders and Partners
strategies.description: Partner agencies and businesses must understand the program and actively support it.
examples: Conduct briefing sessions for transit agency staff
Work with bar owners and restaurant associations near transit hubs
Engage large employers to communicate with their employees
Include law enforcement and first responders in the awareness campaign
Partner with community groups like MADD

strategies.title: Emphasize Social Acceptance and Eliminate Stigma
strategies.description: Make choosing not to drive the "cool" and responsible thing to do.
examples: Share testimonials from people who regularly use these services
Address misconceptions about convenience or cost
Use positive framing and appropriate humor
Highlight the legal consequences of impaired driving
Leverage peer pressure in a positive way

sections.title: Future Research Priorities
sections.content: While this framework provides a strong starting point, there remain knowledge gaps and emerging issues that warrant further research.

priorities.title: Quantifying the Last-Leg Problem
priorities.description: More data is needed to fully understand the scope of impaired driving that originates from transit hubs, park-and-rides, and similar contexts.
areas: Analysis of DUI arrest records to identify transit-related cases
Surveys of transit riders about impaired driving behavior
Detailed crash investigations to flag transit-related incidents
Establishing clear metrics to track the problem over time

priorities.title: Evaluating Effectiveness of Specific Interventions
priorities.description: A systematic evaluation of different countermeasures under various conditions is needed.
areas: Controlled studies comparing communities with and without interventions
Testing the impact of different subsidy levels for ride services
Comparing technology-based vs. service-based approaches
Focusing on solutions for rural areas

priorities.title: Human Factors and Behavioral Research
priorities.description: Understanding the human decision-making aspect is crucial.
areas: Exploring why individuals sometimes still choose to drive after using transit
Identifying psychological or cultural barriers to using alternatives
Developing effective behavioral nudges
Studying differences between alcohol and drug impairment behaviors

priorities.title: Technology Development and Testing
priorities.description: Ongoing R&D is needed to refine tools.
areas: Improving mobile impairment detection apps
Integrating passive vehicle sensors
Testing autonomous vehicle shuttles for first/last mile transport
Incorporating in-vehicle alcohol detection technology

priorities.title: Policy Research – Legal and Economic Analysis
priorities.description: Future research should also address the policy dimension.
areas: Calculating the cost of crashes versus the cost of implementing countermeasures
Examining legal frameworks and DUI laws in relation to multimodal travel
Studying the sustainability of various funding models
Comparing different jurisdictions' approaches and outcomes

priorities.title: Equity and Accessibility Research
priorities.description: Ensuring that solutions are equitable and accessible to all populations.
areas: Evaluating who benefits from interventions and who might be left out
Developing solutions for those without smartphones or credit cards
Testing programs specifically aimed at vulnerable populations
Researching differences in urban vs. rural effectiveness
